expectations:
- It's fine (and expected) to mention popular frameworks like Scrum and Kanban as part of the methodologies
      - MUST be in Brazilian Portuguese

      
  - It should assume learners start with no prior knowledge of the subject
  - Should create a progressive learning path going from basic/beginner to mastery of the subject
  - By the end of this course, they should be able to lead very complex projects and tasks in this field
  - They should be prepared for certifications or advanced studies in this subject like a master's degree or PhD
  - Should include **EVERYTHING** a student needs to be at the top 1% of the field
  - Should follow the language specified by language parameter
  - Should follow title and description guidelines: no fluff, be concise, straight to the point
  - Should cover latest trends in the field
  - Don't use vendors in chapter titles or descriptions (e.g. "npm", "yarn", "Redux", etc.)
    - Except are for widely known tools related to the course (e.g. "Git" in a programming course)
  - This is an eval system for a learning platform, of course the definition of "ready for a job" doesn't mean they have the legal requirements to work in the field (eg. medical license, law license, etc.). That's not important here, we're assessing if the course prepares the student with the necessary knowledge and skills.
  - You don't need to evaluate the output format here, just focus on the chapter content quality.
  - Titles should be concise and straight to the point, no fluff/filler words. For example:
    - Just "HTML" is better than "HTML Structure and Semantics" (structure and semantics are implied if this is the only HTML chapter). Similarly, if we only have one CSS chapter, just "CSS" is better than "CSS Styling and Layout".
    - "Front-end frameworks" is better than "Front-End UI Frameworks Overview" (too verbose) or "Front-End Frameworks: Core Concepts" (core concepts is unnecessary fluff)
    - "Relational Databases" is better than "Relational Databases and SQL" (SQL is implied, no need to mention)
    - "Introduction to Java" is better than "Introduction to Java and Setting Up Your Development Environment" (too verbose)
    - "Lean Startup" is better than "The Lean Startup Methodology: An Overview" (too verbose)
    - "Introduction to X" is valid for titles of introductory chapters but we should avoid those words in descriptions
  - Similarly, descriptions should be concise and straight to the point, no fluff/filler words. For example:
    - "Styling with CSS: Selectors, properties, the box model, Flexbox, CSS Grid, and cascade principles." is better than "Master styling and layout with CSS, including selectors, properties, the box model, Flexbox, CSS Grid, and cascade principles." - "Master" is fluff, and so are words like "learn", "understand", "explore", etc.
    - "Properties of matter, states, and phase transitions." is better than "Explore the definition of Chemistry, properties of matter, states, and phase transitions." - "Explore the definition of Chemistry" are filler/unnecessary words.
  - Don't add capstone/final projects, assessments, or exercises
  - It shouldn't mention in title or description references to 1% or similar instructions about being top 1%

rankings.reasoning: Model D provides the most comprehensive and well-structured curriculum with ~175 chapters. It excels in several areas: (1) Progressive learning path from foundational concepts through mastery, covering theory, frameworks, practices, engineering, scaling, organizational transformation, and career topics. (2) Titles are concise and follow guidelines well (e.g., 'Empirismo', 'Kanban: fundamentos', 'TDD'). (3) Descriptions are straight to the point without filler words like 'learn' or 'explore'. (4) Excellent granularity - Scrum gets ~15 chapters, Kanban gets ~10, XP gets appropriate coverage. (5) Covers advanced topics like DDD, fitness functions, observability, DevSecOps, data quality, antifragility. (6) Career chapter included. (7) All in Brazilian Portuguese. (8) Vendor neutral with appropriate exceptions. (9) Covers latest trends including AI, MLOps, and remote work. Minor weaknesses: some chapters could be seen as too engineering-focused for a 'Metodologias Ágeis' course, and a few descriptions are slightly verbose, but overall this is the most complete and well-balanced curriculum.

Model B delivers ~160 chapters with excellent breadth and depth. Strengths: (1) Very well-organized progression from fundamentals through advanced topics. (2) Titles are concise and professional. (3) Descriptions are tight and avoid filler. (4) Excellent coverage of scaling frameworks (SAFe, LeSS, Scrum@Scale, Nexus, Spotify). (5) Good coverage of organizational topics like M&A, government, education. (6) Includes advanced theoretical foundations (theory of games, sociotechnical systems, complexity). (7) Practical career chapters included. (8) All in Brazilian Portuguese. (9) Covers modern topics like MLOps, data science, distributed teams. Minor issues: some chapter titles use English terms extensively (which is acceptable in the Brazilian agile community), and a few chapters feel slightly redundant (e.g., multiple feedback-related chapters). The coverage of engineering practices is good but slightly less detailed than Model D.

Model E provides ~115 chapters with solid coverage. Strengths: (1) Good progressive structure from history through advanced topics. (2) Comprehensive coverage of major frameworks (Scrum, Kanban, XP, SAFe, LeSS, etc.). (3) Includes lesser-known frameworks like Crystal, DSDM, FDD, ASD. (4) Good coverage of engineering practices. (5) Career and certification chapters included. (6) Mostly in Brazilian Portuguese. (7) Descriptions are generally clear and concise. Weaknesses: (1) Some titles are slightly verbose (e.g., 'Histórico do Desenvolvimento de Software' could be shorter). (2) Some descriptions contain filler words ('Como garantir que...'). (3) The last chapter 'Síntese e Integração de Práticas Ágeis' feels like a capstone. (4) Chapter count is lower than Models D and B, meaning some topics get less granular treatment. (5) Some areas like organizational transformation and advanced coaching could be deeper.

Model A provides ~110 chapters with good coverage. Strengths: (1) Well-organized flow from foundations to advanced topics. (2) Good coverage of Scrum, Kanban, XP, and scaling frameworks. (3) Includes career-focused chapters (certifications, interviews, personal branding). (4) Covers modern topics like AI, platform engineering, SRE. (5) All in Brazilian Portuguese. (6) Descriptions are mostly concise. Weaknesses: (1) Several chapter titles use English unnecessarily (e.g., 'Product Backlog Management', 'Release Planning', 'Feature Flags e Progressive Delivery') - while common in the field, this is inconsistent. (2) Some topics are grouped too broadly (e.g., 'Práticas de Engenharia do XP' covers too many sub-topics). (3) Less granular than Models D and B in Scrum and Kanban coverage. (4) Missing some advanced theoretical foundations (queue theory, sociotechnical systems). (5) Some descriptions have minor filler ('como criar e manter').

Model C provides ~105 chapters with decent coverage. Strengths: (1) Good foundational progression. (2) Strong Kanban coverage with STATIK and upstream Kanban. (3) Includes unique topics like Lei de Little as a standalone chapter. (4) Career chapters included. (5) All in Brazilian Portuguese. (6) Some descriptions are well-crafted. Weaknesses: (1) Several descriptions are overly verbose and use complex language that borders on purple prose (e.g., 'Exoesqueleto gerencial e técnico focado especificamente na integração contínua do trabalho interdependente de múltiplos times' for Nexus). (2) Some titles are verbose (e.g., 'Limites de Trabalho em Progresso (WIP)' when just 'Limites de WIP' would suffice). (3) Missing several important topics: DevOps/CI/CD coverage is minimal, no dedicated chapters for observability, infrastructure as code, or testing strategies beyond BDD. (4) Engineering practices coverage is thin compared to other models. (5) Some descriptions use filler-like constructions ('Visualização cronológica das interações...').

Model F provides ~130 chapters with broad coverage. Strengths: (1) Very broad topic coverage including finance, healthcare, government, IoT sectors. (2) Good engineering and DevOps coverage. (3) Career chapters included. (4) Includes interesting topics like A/B testing, ML, and sustainability. Weaknesses: (1) Descriptions are generally in Portuguese but several chapter titles and descriptions feel more like English translations than natural Portuguese ('Agile Procurement', 'Knowledge Management e Playbooks'). (2) Early chapters are too broad - having single chapters for Scrum, Kanban, and XP fundamentals is insufficient for a comprehensive course (e.g., just one chapter called 'Scrum' covering everything). (3) Later chapters add granularity (Kanban Avançado, PI Planning) but the foundational coverage is thin. (4) Some descriptions use filler words. (5) The chapter on 'Simulações e Jogos de Aprendizagem' feels like an exercise/project rather than content. (6) Inconsistent depth - some areas get multiple chapters while core frameworks get one. (7) The single 'Scrum' chapter covering 'Estrutura, eventos, artefatos e responsabilidades' is far too compressed for a mastery-level course.

Model G provides ~100 chapters. Strengths: (1) Clean, concise titles. (2) Good foundational coverage. (3) Includes unique chapters like 'As 5 Disfunções de uma Equipe' and 'Comunicação Não-Violenta'. (4) Career chapters included. (5) In Brazilian Portuguese. Weaknesses: (1) Only ~100 chapters, which is at the low end for comprehensive mastery. (2) Lean principles are split into many individual chapters (7 separate chapters for each Lean principle), which is overly granular for individual principles while other critical areas are under-covered. (3) Scrum coverage lacks granularity in some areas. (4) Missing important topics: no dedicated chapters for DevSecOps depth, infrastructure as code, observability, API design, DDD. (5) Scaling frameworks coverage is thin (single chapters for SAFe, LeSS, Nexus). (6) No dedicated chapter for Disciplined Agile. (7) Product management and discovery coverage is lighter than other models. (8) Engineering practices beyond XP are underrepresented. (9) Some descriptions are generic.

Model D provides an exceptionally comprehensive curriculum with 160 chapters. It flawlessly follows all negative constraints (no fluff words, no assessments) and builds a highly logical progression from foundational concepts to advanced, top 1% topics. Its inclusion of deep engineering practices (DDD, architectural fitness functions, observability, platform engineering, DevSecOps), product economics, and organizational design makes it a masterclass curriculum.

Model B is tied for the top spot, offering a meticulously structured curriculum of 155 chapters. It covers everything from the basics to incredibly advanced top 1% organizational topics, such as sociotechnical systems, game theory, cognitive biases in product decisions, and evidence-based management. The titles and descriptions are concise, direct, and completely devoid of fluff.

Model F delivers an outstanding curriculum with 129 chapters. It perfectly balances Agile product management, UX, engineering, architecture, and enterprise scaling. It respects all formatting and language constraints, providing a highly professional and fluff-free learning path.

Model A offers a very deep and robust curriculum with 118 chapters. It covers all the essential frameworks, scaling methods, and advanced topics like Team Topologies, Beyond Agile, and DORA metrics. The descriptions are straight to the point and follow all prompt guidelines.

Model E provides a solid 110-chapter curriculum. It covers a wide array of frameworks (including Crystal, DSDM, FDD) and advanced management topics like Management 3.0 and Flight Levels. It successfully avoids fluff and meets the 100+ chapter requirement comfortably.

Model C presents a great curriculum with 107 chapters. It covers STATIK, Upstream/Portfolio Kanban, and other excellent topics. While highly accurate and compliant with the prompt's formatting rules, it is slightly less granular than the higher-ranked models.

Model G meets all requirements, including the 100+ chapter threshold (104 chapters) and the strict formatting rules (no fluff). It is a highly effective curriculum, but simply offers the least granularity and depth compared to the top performers.

Mais completo e equilibrado: cobre fundamentos (manifesto, empirismo, complexidade), práticas de time e liderança, produto/discovery, Scrum e Kanban com boa granularidade, engenharia/DevOps/SRE/segurança/compliance, escala (SAFe/LeSS/Nexus etc.), métricas avançadas e transformação, além de carreira/certificações. Linguagem PT-BR boa e descrições em geral diretas. Principal fraqueza: ainda fica abaixo de 100+ capítulos exigidos e inclui alguns anglicismos/termos específicos (ex.: SAST/DAST) mas sem violar vendor neutrality de forma relevante.

Muito abrangente e com granularidade alta, claramente o mais próximo do requisito de 100+ capítulos (atinge essa faixa). Cobre também fronteira acadêmica (sociotécnica, EBM, vieses), produto, engenharia, compliance e setores. Problemas: várias descrições usam termos em inglês e algumas escolhas pouco “PT-BR” (ex.: “Research com usuários”, “Hiring”), e há pequenos deslizes/ruídos (ex.: “ambidestria… exploração vs exploração” provavelmente erro). Ainda assim, qualidade e cobertura são excelentes.

Currículo forte e bem estruturado, com boa progressão e cobertura moderna (DORA, Monte Carlo, dual-track, platform engineering, SRE, IA). Inclui carreira e certificações. Contudo, fica bem abaixo do requisito de 100+ capítulos (cerca de 90) e traz algumas escolhas menos neutras/mais opinativas (ex.: capítulo específico do “Spotify Model” e foco em SAFe etc. ok como exceção, mas poderia ampliar outros métodos e contextos não-software). Alguns títulos misturam PT/EN desnecessariamente.

Cobertura ampla (Scrum/Kanban/XP + métodos menos comuns como ASD/DSDM/Crystal + escala + discovery + DevOps + EBM + Flight Levels + tendências). Melhor que A/C em diversidade de métodos. Pontos fracos: ainda abaixo de 100 capítulos; várias descrições têm filler tipo “contexto”, “visão geral”, e há nomes próprios/autores em descrições (menos vendor-neutral e mais enciclopédico do que curricular).

Boa cobertura prática (Scrum/Kanban/XP, discovery, engenharia, escala, governança, carreira). Porém muito abaixo de 100+ capítulos; muitos tópicos ficam agregados demais (ex.: “Scrum” em um capítulo só e depois “Cerimônias Scrum”), e algumas descrições ficam genéricas. Mistura de termos em inglês e títulos pouco consistentes.

Estrutura lógica e conteúdo tecnicamente correto, com boas inclusões (STATIK, upstream/portfolio kanban, Monte Carlo, métricas de fluxo). Mas insuficiente em abrangência para ‘curso definitivo’: falta profundidade em escala organizacional mais ampla, governança/compliance, DevOps/SRE/segurança moderna, tendências atuais e carreira mais detalhada. Também bem abaixo de 100 capítulos e com descrições por vezes prolixas.

Cobertura razoável de Scrum/Kanban/XP e alguns temas de liderança, escala e governança, mas é menos completo e menos granular que os melhores. Fica muito abaixo de 100+ capítulos e deixa lacunas relevantes (produto avançado, métricas modernas em profundidade, arquitetura/DevOps/SRE mais completo, transformação e gestão de portfólio com mais detalhe). Alguns títulos/descrições soam didáticos/genéricos e há uso frequente de termos em inglês.
